title: The belief in a negative interdependence of math and verbal abilities as determinant of academic self-concepts
abstract: Background. The internal/external frame of reference (I/E) model by Marsh (1986) assumes intra-individual dimensional comparisons in which students compare their own achievements in one subject with their achievements in other subjects. These comparison processes should lead to negative paths from achievement in one subject (e.g. maths) on self-concept in another subject (e.g. verbal domains). Aims. Within this study, we investigated the impact of students' belief in a negative interdependence of maths and verbal abilities, that is, whether students think of maths and verbal abilities as negatively correlated or not, on the impact of dimensional comparisons. Methods. Maths and German grades, academic self-concepts in maths and German, and a new scale on the beliefs in a negative interdependence of maths and verbal abilities students were assessed (N ¼ 1; 443). Results. The importance of the negative interdependence beliefs could be shown: stronger beliefs in a negative interdependence of maths and verbal ability are accompanied by more negative path coefficients from grades in one subject to academic self-concepts in the other subject. Conclusions. Dimensional comparisons seem to be of particular importance for students with negative interdependence beliefs.

abstract.text: Background. The internal/external frame of reference (I/E) model by Marsh (1986) assumes intra-individual dimensional comparisons in which students compare their own achievements in one subject with their achievements in other subjects. These comparison processes should lead to negative paths from achievement in one subject (e.g. maths) on self-concept in another subject (e.g. verbal domains). Aims. Within this study, we investigated the impact of students' belief in a negative interdependence of maths and verbal abilities, that is, whether students think of maths and verbal abilities as negatively correlated or not, on the impact of dimensional comparisons. Methods. Maths and German grades, academic self-concepts in maths and German, and a new scale on the beliefs in a negative interdependence of maths and verbal abilities students were assessed (N ¼ 1; 443). Results. The importance of the negative interdependence beliefs could be shown: stronger beliefs in a negative interdependence of maths and verbal ability are accompanied by more negative path coefficients from grades in one subject to academic self-concepts in the other subject. Conclusions. Dimensional comparisons seem to be of particular importance for students with negative interdependence beliefs.

body_text.text: When developing domain-specific self-concepts of ability, students have to integrate achievement-related information from various sources. According to the internal/ external frame of reference model (Marsh, 1986 (Marsh, , 1990 , they compare their levels of academic ability using two different, but connected, frames of reference. Within the external frame of reference, students make social comparisons, that is, they compare their ability and achievement to the perceived abilities and achievements of their classmates. This external reference serves as a basis for their maths and verbal self-concepts. For example, if their verbal achievement is higher than their classmates' achievement, then their verbal self-concept tends to be higher too. Because achievements in maths and verbal school subjects are typically positively correlated, these social comparisons lead to the expectation that domain-specific maths and verbal self-concepts are positively correlated as well.

Processes of dimensional comparison 1 (Möller & Köller, 2001a) have been drawn on to explain the domain-specificity of academic self-concepts and the typically only very low correlations between verbal and maths self-concepts. According to the internal frame of reference, students evaluate their achievements in any particular subject in relation to their achievements in other subjects. Aside from the external (social) comparison, the dimensional comparison process is used as the second basis for the formation of a self-concept in each subject. According to this process, lower maths skills lead to a lower maths self-concept based on external comparisons with classmates' achievements in maths, but to a higher verbal self-concept, based on internal comparisons with their own better achievements in verbal domains. The relative weight of both comparison processes explains the moderate or near zero correlation between maths and verbal self-concepts. These patterns were found in a variety of studies on different age groups with different methodologies in several countries (Bong, 1998; Faber, 1992; Köller, Klemmert, Möller, & Baumert, 1999; Marsh, 1986 Marsh, , 1990 Marsh, Walker, & Debus, 1991; Möller & Köller, 2001b; Skaalvik & Rankin, 1990 Tay, Licht, & Tate, 1995; Williams & Montgomery, 1995) and for different ability groups (Möller, Streblow, & Pohlmann, 2002; Plucker & Stocking, 2001) . Empirical support for the I/E model is usually based on such correlational data. There are also a few important experimental or field-experimental studies on the I/E model (see Möller & Husemann, in press; Möller & Köller, 2001a) .

The negative path coefficients from achievement in one subject on self-concept in the other subject can be seen as indicators of a contrast effect. Students compare their achievements in the two subjects and this comparison leads to contrast effects between their self-concepts. The self-concept in the intra-individual better dimension increases, whereas the self-concept in the intra-individually worse dimension decreases.

Until now, less attention was paid to individual variables influencing the effects of dimensional comparisons described in the I/E model. While students' sex, age (with the exception of very young students; see Marsh, 1986) , countries, and methodological factors seem to be of relatively low importance for the question mentioned, different subjective theories about the interdependence between maths and verbal abilities may be important. It is the main purpose of this paper to investigate the role of students' belief in a negative interdependence of maths and verbal abilities on the I/E patterns.

Subjective theories about ability are shown to have enormous impact on achievement motivation, task choice, and performance. This could be shown by the theoretical contributions and the empirical work by, for example, Harter (1998) , or Marsh and Hattie (1996) on the hierarchical structure and on the domain-specificity of self-evaluations, or by the work of Eccles (1983) on the malleability of children's
body_text.section: Beliefs in a negative interdependence of maths and verbal abilities

body_text.text: Reproduction in any form (including the internet) is prohibited without prior permission from the Society competence beliefs and their impact on young children's development (see in particular Wigfield et al., 1997) .

One other prominent example is the attribution process that deals with students thoughts about the causes of success and failure (Weiner, 1979) . More specifically, subjective theories about the nature of intelligence or ability are dealt with in educational psychology. For example, students' assumptions about the mutability of intelligence, that is, whether they have a more incremental or entity theory, determine whether students are more or less oriented on achievement or learning goals (Dweck & Leggett, 1988) . In a similar way, Nicholls (1992) pointed out that goal orientations are based on subjective theories and beliefs about the causes of success. Task-oriented students believe in interest, effort, cooperation with classmates, and deeper learning strategies as sources of scholastic success. Ego-oriented persons, in contrast, believe in competition and social comparisons as the basis of scholastic success.

One important determinant of the way individuals consider, in particular, the internal frame of reference may be their subjective belief about the negative interdependence of abilities; that is, how much they think of maths and verbal ability as negatively correlated. Skaalvik and Rankin (1992) assumed that the effects of dimensional comparisons depend on students' subjective estimations about the relation between their own ability in maths and verbal domains. They suggest that the negative contrast effects from achievement in one subject on self-concept in the other subject will not occur for all students. According to this assumption, dimensional comparisons could be without consequences if students rate their maths and verbal ability as equally good or bad. Skaalvik and Rankin asked their participants 'if they thought they were better in maths or better in verbal skills or equal in these activities' (p. 271). As proposed, significant negative effects from achievement on the non-corresponding self-concept were only revealed for students who differ in their evaluation of their maths and their verbal ability (in spite of their positive correlations between the two achievements r ¼ :63). Students who rated their maths and verbal ability equally, showed no negative significant contrast effects from achievement on noncorresponding self-concept. For this group of students, there were also significant positive correlations between maths and verbal self-concepts (corresponding with their positive achievement correlations r ¼ :69).

Skaalvik and Rankin conceptualized their measure as adequate to represent differences between maths and verbal self-concepts within the single student by categorizing the students in different groups. Students which attest themselves a similar ability in both subjects should only reveal small self-concept differences, positive selfconcept correlations, and almost no contrast effects. However, Skaalvik and Rankin's approach refers to a substantial research requirement in I/E research. As Bong (1998) and Marsh and Yeung (2001) have stated, the conditions of the contrast effects from one subject on self-concept in another subject, and thereby the antecedents of dimensional comparison processes, should be a topic of research. There should be some differences between students in the way they carry out the juxtaposition of both the social and the dimensional comparison process. One important determinant of the way individuals consider the internal frame of reference may be their subjective belief about the interdependence of maths and verbal abilities; that is, how they think about the domainspecificity of ability in general, whether maths and verbal ability are negatively correlated or not. This ability belief perhaps goes beyond the students' estimation whether their own abilities in the two subjects are quite different or not. From this perspective, our study firstly tries to demonstrate that beliefs in a negative interdependence of maths and verbal abilities is more than just a reflection of differentiated self-perceived abilities and secondly tries to evaluate its moderating role in the I/E model. However, recent work on epistemological beliefs (Hofer, 2000) also deals with the domain-specificity of the nature of knowledge. Results in a study by Buehl, Alexander, and Murphy (2002) suggested that students possess certain domain-specific beliefs about knowledge, for example, in mathematics and history. Beliefs about need for effort and beliefs about integration of information and problem-solving were shown to be domain-specific. The belief in a negative interdependency of maths and verbal ability may be seen like an epistemological belief dealing with the relation of abilities in two domains.

It is the main purpose of our study to test the assumption that such a belief in a negative interdependence reinforces the negative effects of achievement in one domain on self-concept in the other domain. For example, some students may think of maths and verbal ability as uncorrelated or even negatively correlated. For them, the information that a person got a good exam grade in maths means that this person tends to have a lower verbal ability. Therefore, good grades in maths lead to higher maths selfconcepts but may reduce verbal self-concepts. This is just the process assumed, as the basis of the contrast effects from achievement in the one subject on self-concept in the other subject in the I/E model. Other students may believe that maths and verbal ability are positively correlated (as they, like many studies in fact show, obviously are). For them, the information that a person got a good exam grade in maths means that this person tends to have an above average verbal ability, too. For these persons with less negative interdependence beliefs, the contrast effects of achievement in the one subject on self-concept in the other subject as postulated in the I/E model should be smaller, or even zero. To illustrate this assumption, imagine a student who takes their good maths achievements as an indicator of a high general intelligence, consequently expecting to be good in verbal subjects as in maths, and therefore develops a high verbal self-concept. Through this process, an internal comparison can lead even to a positive effect when an excellent achievement in one domain tends to raise a students' self-concept in another domain as shown by Möller, Pohlmann, Streblow, and Köller (2004) for the relations between maths and physics.
Our hypotheses are as follows:

(1) Achievement in one subject will positively affect self-concept in the corresponding domain and negatively affect self-concept in the non-corresponding domain as the I/E model postulates. (2) The belief in a negative interdependence of maths and verbal ability will reinforce the negative effect of achievement in one domain on self-concept in the noncorresponding domain.

Participants and procedure Participants were N ¼ 1; 443 seventh to tenth grade students (55.0% female) from selective junior high schools in Germany. Age was between 12 and 18 years (M ¼ 13:92; SD ¼ 1:38). In regular school lessons, participants were given a questionnaire assessing their grades, the negative interdependence of maths and verbal abilities belief and their self-concepts in the school subjects of maths and German in randomized order. Participation was voluntary and anonymous, and students were assured that their teachers would not receive any information about their answers.
Self-concept for each subject was measured with a 5-item scale (Möller & Köller, 2001b) that was adequately reliable (Cronbach's alpha for both subjects was identical, a ¼ :90).

The five items were: 'I would prefer math much more if it weren't so hard', 'Nobody's perfect, but I'm just not good at math', 'With some of the things in math, I know from the start that I just won't get it', 'Math just does not appeal to me', 'Even if I do my best in math, I do not perform very well'. Students responded to each item on a 6-point scale (from 0 ¼ disagree to 5 ¼ agree). Scores were reverse-coded so that higher scores indicate a higher self-concept. Items do not verbalize explicitly any kind of social or dimensional comparison. The wording of the items for the subjects was strictly parallel except for the specific school subject (i.e. math, German). Previous studies have provided evidence for the validity and reliability of the scale (e.g. Möller & Köller, 2000) .

In that study, all correlation coefficients of the domain-specific self-concept scales with actual grades in different subjects (German, mathematics, history, and physics) were above .60 and internal consistencies (Cronbach's a) were above .75. In the present study, correlation between maths achievement and self-concept was r ¼ :58, and correlation between German achievement and self-concept was r ¼ :48. Because access to students' actual grades was restricted, and for economical reasons, grades were obtained by self-report. Students were asked: 'Which grade were you given in your last report in the following subjects?' Grades in reports had been announced 1-2 months before the investigation began. In our study, students wrote their grade in a box beside the subject name. Grades in German schools range between 1 ¼ very good and 6 ¼ poor, but are reverse-coded, so that positive correlations between grade and selfconcept within a domain are expected. Self-reports of grades may be vulnerable to intentional or unintentional under-and over-estimation. Some USA studies have shown that students tend to overestimate their GPA (see Dobbins, Farh, & Werbel, 1993; Flake & Goldman, 1991; Goldman, Flake, & Matheson, 1990; Shepperd, 1993; Trice, 1990; Zimmerman, Caldwell, & Bernat, 2002 ; but see Frucot & Cook, 1994; Kirk & Sereda, 1969) . In the German school system, where grades are given in the form of whole numbers for single subjects (German, mathematics, English, physics, biology, sports, music, etc.), biased self-reports of grades seem to be less likely as Möller et al. (2004) showed in a small empirical study (see Helmke, 1992 , for additional support).

The NAB was measured with a 6-item scale that was adequately reliable (Cronbach's a ¼ :77). The six items were: 'I think that some people are talented in math whereas others are talented in verbal domains', 'Ability is subject-specific. People are either achieving well in math or in languages', 'Students who are not as good in math have their strengths in verbal affairs', 'There are only a few people who are equally talented in math and German', 'Students who do well in math often do not achieve so well in German', 'A students' grades in math and German tend to be quite different'. We included five items assessing the relations of ability in two domains as well as one item assessing the relations of grades in the two domains. 2 Students responded to each item on a 6-point scale (from 0 ¼ disagree to 5 ¼ agree). Responses to the items were summed and mean scores were calculated. Higher scores in the ability beliefs scale indicate beliefs in a negative interdependency between maths and verbal ability. For means of further analyses, students were separated into two groups, below or above the NAB median (Median ¼ 2:50).

To ascertain the validity of the ability belief scale students from two different samples were asked for their beliefs in the negative interdependency of abilities in different school subjects. Within Sample 1, 130 (50.0% female) students were asked for their beliefs about the negative interdependency of abilities between German and maths and between German and English. As expected, the negativity of the interdependence was significantly, tð128Þ ¼ 7:66; p , :001, higher for the German-maths combination (M ¼ 2:57; SD ¼ 0:61) than for the German-English combination (M ¼ 2:07; SD ¼ 0:51). Within Sample 2, 168 (60.9% female) students were asked for their beliefs about the negative interdependency of abilities between maths and German and between maths and chemistry. Again, as expected, the negativity of the interdependence was significantly, tð167Þ ¼ 14:32; p , :001, higher for the maths-German combination (M ¼ 2:60, SD ¼ 0:66) than for the maths-chemistry combination (M ¼ 1:89, SD ¼ 0:46). Obviously students perceived German and maths ability as more distinct factors than they perceived two scientific subjects or two languages. Therefore, these small pre-studies indicate some face validity to the scale. Table 1 shows the variables' means (SD) and the correlations among all achievement and self-concept variables and ability beliefs for the whole sample and the two subsamples divided on the NAB median. As postulated by the I/E model, the achievement correlation was higher (r ¼ :34) than the self-concept correlation (r ¼ 2:08). Ability belief scores were moderately negatively correlated with achievements and selfconcepts. The correlation between the two achievements in German and maths is slightly higher in the group with less specific ability beliefs. As expected, maths and German self-concept correlations differ between the two groups and are -in spite of the still positive achievement correlations -negative for students who believe in a negative interdependence of maths and verbal abilities. Within the domains, correlations between achievement and self-concept are similar for both groups. More important, NAB scores are only moderately correlated with individual absolute differences in grades (r ¼ :18) and self-concepts (r ¼ :33).

Data analyses were conducted by means of SEM. A detailed presentation of SEM is beyond the scope of the present investigation, but is available elsewhere (e.g. Hayduck, 1987; Jöreskog & Sörbom, 1993) . Following Marsh, Balla, and Hau (1996) and Marsh, Balla, and McDonald (1988) , we emphasize the Tucker-Lewis index (TLI) and the root mean square error of approximation (RMSEA) to evaluate goodness of fit which, compared with x 2 -statistics, are less sensitive to sample size. According to recommendations by the authors mentioned above, a sufficient model fit is indicated by TLI-values above .90 (some authors recommend .95) and RMSEA-values below .08. Although tests of statistical significance and indices of fit help to evaluate the fit of a model, there is ultimately some degree of subjective and professional judgment in the selection of a 'best' model. As a part of AMOS 4.01 (Arbuckle, 1999) the full information maximum likelihood (FIML) was used to estimate unbiased covariance matrices in the case of missing data (Wothke, 2000) In the first step of our analyses, we were interested in how NAB moderates the effects of grades on maths and German self-concepts. We analyzed a model in which NAB should affect the I/E pattern between grades and the two academic self-concepts. Statistically expressed, we expected significant NAB £ Grade interactions on the selfconcept variables. In AMOS, moderating effects in SEM are to be examined in two ways (if no latent variables were modelled), both of them used in our analysis. The first way is analogous to regression analysis with interaction effects to directly integrate the product terms into the path analysis as additional predictors, here NAB £ Grade. To receive meaningful interpretations, the single scores have to be z-standardized before building the product terms (see Cronbach, 1987) . Otherwise there will result strong multicollinearity within the model. Consequently, the z-standardized multiplied grade and NAB scores build the interaction terms to ascertain the impact of NAB on the relations between grades and self-concepts. The other strategy is to dichotomize the moderator variable to establish two groups with high versus low scores. In the next step, the hypothesis is tested if the paths of a specified model are different in both groups.
body_text.section: Moderating effects of the negative interdependence of ability beliefs on the relation between grades and academic self-concepts: Findings of structural equation modelling (SEM)

body_text.text: Within the two-group-analyses, the Akaikes information criterion (AIC) is used additionally. AIC is a fit indice which results from the additive connection of the models x 2 -score and its number of parameters. Logically, each additional estimation of a model parameter reduces the x 2 -score, thereby raising the number of estimated model parameters. If the gain in the x 2 -score is rather low in relation to the additional parameters, AIC increases. If the gain in x 2 -scores is rather high in relation to the number of model parameters, AIC decreases. If two models with different numbers of parameters are compared, the model with a lower AIC is more adequate. There are no other statistical tests using AIC.
body_text.section: Moderating effects of the negative interdependence of ability beliefs on the relation between grades and academic self-concepts: Findings of structural equation modelling (SEM)

body_text.text: SEM is used as state-of-the-art testing the I/E model. However, the problem with the current data is its hierarchical structure, that is, students are nested in classes. Therefore, we rerun the analyses with hierarchical linear modelling (HLM, Bryk, Raudenbush, & Congdon, 1994) to test whether the consideration of the class level makes any differences for the results of the SEM analyses. Figure 1 presents a path model including the interaction terms 'negative interdependence of math and verbal ability beliefs (NAB) £ achievement'. The model fit is rather satisfactory (x 2 ð79Þ ¼ 651:55, TLI ¼ :98, RMSEA ¼ :071). The links between grades and self-concepts were as is expected in the I/E model. Math grade affected maths self-concept positively (.65) and German self-concept negatively (2 .30). A similar pattern resulted for the German grade (.58 on German self-concept, 2 .24 on maths self-concept). The NAB term negatively affects the maths and the German selfconcepts. The belief in a negative interdependence of maths and verbal ability seems to lower students' maths and verbal self-concepts. Interaction terms positively influenced the corresponding self-concepts (maths: .13; German .09). The positive effects on the corresponding self-concepts may be interpreted as reinforcing the impact from grades on corresponding self-concepts. For example, students with high scores in the ability belief scale (who believe that maths and verbal abilities are quite distinct) and good grades in maths (German), and therefore high interaction term scores, had higher maths (verbal) self-concepts. More interestingly, the interaction term negatively influenced the divergent self-concepts (maths: 2 .11; German 2 .08). The negative effects on the noncorresponding self-concepts may be interpreted as reinforcing the impact from grades on non-corresponding self-concepts: students with high scores in the ability belief scale and good grades in maths (German), and therefore high interaction term scores had Figure 1 . Path model of the relations between maths and German achievements, self-concepts, and NAB (MA ¼ maths achievement, GA ¼ German achievement, NAB ¼ negative interdependent ability belief, MA £ NAB ¼ interaction 'MA £ NAB', GA £ NAB ¼ interaction 'GA £ NAB', MSC ¼ maths self-concept, GSC ¼ German self-concept; ** p , :01).
body_text.section: Moderating effects of the negative interdependence of ability beliefs on the relation between grades and academic self-concepts: Findings of structural equation modelling (SEM)

body_text.text: lower German (maths) self-concepts. Therefore, strong beliefs in the negative interdependence of maths and verbal ability beliefs tend to reinforce the contrast effects from grades on non-corresponding self-concepts as well as the positive effects from grades on the corresponding self-concepts. Less negative interdependence beliefs therefore diminish the contrast effects as well as the positive effects from grades on the corresponding self-concepts.
body_text.section: Moderating effects of the negative interdependence of ability beliefs on the relation between grades and academic self-concepts: Findings of structural equation modelling (SEM)

body_text.text: After rerunning the analysis with HLM (Bryk et al., 1994) , an identical pattern of results was retrieved. All path coefficients were significant and had the same direction as in AMOS. The most important path coefficients from the interaction term 'NAB £ Grade' on the divergent self-concepts were for maths 2 .11 and for German 2 .07, and therefore supported the results retrieved in AMOS.
body_text.section: Moderating effects of the negative interdependence of ability beliefs on the relation between grades and academic self-concepts: Findings of structural equation modelling (SEM)

body_text.text: Altogether, the coefficient pattern confirms the relevance of NAB as a moderator of the divergent effects from grades to non-corresponding self-concepts. To illustrate these moderator effects, additional two-group analyses were carried out. According to their NAB scores, students were dichotomized by median. Subsequently, the patterns between grades and self-concepts in both groups were compared. Technically, it was to examine whether a group-invariant model shows better or worse fit than a groupspecific model in which the paths are allowed to vary between the groups. To examine further which paths contribute to the difference between the two groups, respectively, a single model parameter was estimated as group-specific, whereas all the other parameters were fixed as group-invariant. If the fit indices show a better model fit for the model with group-specific paths, then the differences between both groups are seen as caused by these paths. Table 2 shows the fit indices for the two-group analyses. Model 1 assumes that all path coefficients from grades on self-concept in both groups are identical. Model 2 assumes group-specific path coefficients and correlations. Fit indices show that Model 1 fits quite well. For Model 2, TLI and RMSEA are likewise quite satisfactory. However, there is an important difference between the two models. The x 2 -difference between the models is highly significant and the AIC is lower in Model 2. Figure 2 illustrates the group-specific coefficients.
body_text.section: Moderating effects of the negative interdependence of ability beliefs on the relation between grades and academic self-concepts: Findings of structural equation modelling (SEM)

body_text.text: An additional analysis was carried out to examine whether there were any gender differences in the relations between grades and self-concepts. Technically speaking, AMOS compares whether the fit of a group-invariant model is as good as or worse than the fit of a group-specific model with different path coefficients for both groups. Model 1 assumes that all path coefficients from the grades to the self-concepts as well as the correlations between grades are identical for boys and girls. In contrast, Model 2
body_text.section: Moderating effects of the negative interdependence of ability beliefs on the relation between grades and academic self-concepts: Findings of structural equation modelling (SEM)

body_text.text: Reproduction in any form (including the internet) is prohibited without prior permission from the Society contains group-specific path coefficients and correlations. Fit indices indicate a similar, good fit for both models. The x 2 -difference is not significant, therefore, it can be assumed that the results are generalizable across both gender groups (Table 3) .

With regard to the I/E model, it is to state that the results of our study support expectations based on the effect of external as well as internal frames of reference as often described in research on the I/E model. However, the main purpose of this study was an extension to the I/E model: to investigate the consequences of different ability beliefs on the links between achievement and self-concept. For this purpose a scale was established to cover students' thoughts about the relations between maths and verbal ability and achievement. The scale was quite reliable and successful in predicting students' ratings in a small pre-study. Students had more negative interdependence beliefs when they had to rate the maths-German combination than when they had to rate the maths-chemistry or the German-English combination. The main assumption was that students who think of maths and verbal subjects as negatively-related domains are more likely to show more negative paths from achievement in one subject on self-concept in the other subject. As expected, the achievement/self-concept links across the subjects were influenced by the negativity of the interdependence beliefs as the interpretation of the interaction term effects demonstrated. The contrast effects from achievement in one subject on self-concept in the other subject increased with stronger beliefs in a negative interdependence of maths and verbal ability. With decreasing negativity of the interdependence beliefs, weaker Figure 2 . Separate path models for students with low (first score) and high (second score) scores in the NAB scale (MA ¼ maths achievement, GA ¼ German achievement, MSC ¼ maths self-concept, GSC ¼ German self-concept; ** p , :01). negative divergent paths from grades on non-corresponding self-concepts resulted. Beliefs in the negative interdependency of maths and verbal abilities seem to strengthen the patterns described in the I/E model. Beside these differences, there are some similarities between the coefficients for the low and high NAB groups. Therefore, the I/E model fits to the data in both groups. Only the achievement correlations and the negative paths from achievements to non-corresponding self-concepts seem to differ substantially between the groups. Just these differences confirm the relevance of the belief in the negativity of the interdependence of maths and verbal abilities as a moderator of the divergent effects from grades to non-corresponding self-concepts beyond the impact of students' own grade or self-concept differences in the two domains which are statistically controlled for.

When these results are related to the results of Skaalvik and Rankin (1992) , it is to state that our purpose was different. We wanted to study students' assumptions according to the relation between maths and verbal achievement and ability, whereas Skaalvik and Rankin asked their students for their intra-individual differences between their maths and verbal self-concepts. Each strategy seems to lead to different results. Skaalvik and Rankin revealed that there were no inverse effects from achievement in one domain on self-concept in the other domain if students think that they themselves are equally achieving in both domains. Our study shows that the belief in a negative interdependency of maths and verbal abilities strengthens the negative paths, whereas they are diminished for students with less negative interdependent ability beliefs. This process seems to be relatively independent from students' own achievement differences as the weak correlation between NAB scores and the grade differences showed. More importantly, the NAB scale is only moderately correlated with absolute differences between self-concepts, therefore it measures ability beliefs relatively independently from self-concept differences.

A point that needs to be mentioned pertains to the validity of our results which are based on cross-sectional data. Longitudinal studies can help to get stronger evidence about the impact of such ability beliefs on self-concept development. In addition, longitudinal studies can help to test our assumption that the belief in a negative interdependence of abilities affects academic self-concepts. Other causal directions are plausible, for example, self-concept differences may affect the negativity of the interdependence beliefs. With regard to the problems associated with self-reported grades, such longitudinal studies should deal with students' actual grades whenever possible.

To further analyse the role of ability beliefs, experimental studies are needed. Positive as well as negative and independent beliefs about ability in two different achievement tasks may be experimentally induced. It is to hypothesize with regard to our results that students in the group with negatively interdependent ability beliefs should contrast much more in their task-specific self-concepts than students from the other groups.

For educational concerns, it was often shown that self-concept is one of the most important issues in students' development since it is a good predictor of future interest and achievement (see Helmke & Van Aken, 1995) . Additionally, subject-specific selfconcepts were demonstrated to influence students' course selection (Köller, Daniels, Schnabel, & Baumert, 2000; Marsh & Yeung, 1997) . Consequently, students who believe in a negative interdependency between maths and verbal ability may unfortunately tend to avoid special subjects when they think that they achieve better in other domains (Hannover & Kessels, 2004) . When such perceptions are only due to small achievement differences, this may lead to premature specialization. Such misinterpretations may be prevented when students develop less negatively interdependent ability beliefs. From this point of view it could be fruitful for good students to develop less negative interdependent ability beliefs to prevent premature differentiation of subject-specific self-concepts and, therefore, one-sided course selections. On the other hand, weaker students may profit from the belief that maths and verbal ability are negatively correlated. When a weaker student achieves poorly in one subject (e.g. maths), such beliefs hinder them to generalize their perception of lack of ability to verbal domains and perhaps prevent from motivational shortcomings in the verbal domain.

We prefer to use this term instead of the term internal comparison since there are some other kinds of internal comparisons such as, for example, temporal comparisons (seeSkaalvik & Skaalvik, 2002).Jens Möller et al.
Jens Möller et al.

Whereas ability and grades are theoretically distinct, they are commonly highly correlated and, more important, in the context of the ability belief scale, the integration of the grades relation into the scale may be plausible. However, empirically the exclusion of the items on grade relation does not make any difference in the results.
